content: The Act titled "Strengthening Public Health Protections in Major Disasters and Emergencies Act of 2007" amends the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act to include a new section 409 for the protection of health and safety of individuals in a disaster area. The new section 409 of the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act defines an "individual" as including workers and volunteers who respond to disasters, such as police officers, firefighters, emergency medical technicians, urban search and rescue team members, and other relief workers determined appropriate by the President. The new section 409 of the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act defines an "individual" as including workers and volunteers who respond to disasters, such as police officers, firefighters, emergency medical technicians, urban search and rescue team members, and other relief workers determined appropriate by the President. The term 'medical institution' includes hospital facilities and accredited public or nonprofit schools of medicine. The term 'program' refers to activities carried out for a disaster area. The new section 409 of the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act defines an "individual" as including workers and volunteers who respond to disasters. The term 'substance of concern' refers to chemicals or substances associated with potential health effects in disaster areas. If substances of concern are released in a declared disaster area, the President may implement a program for health and safety protection. The program under the new section 409 of the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act ensures that individuals responding to disasters are monitored for potential health and mental impacts of substances of concern. They receive necessary healthcare referrals and information from monitoring is used to prevent future health impacts. Activities may include clinical health examinations and preventive measures. The program under the new section 409 of the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act involves activities such as collecting environmental exposure data, conducting health examinations, establishing exposure registries, studying health impacts, and providing assistance with health coverage eligibility. The program established under paragraph (1) of the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act includes timely commencement of activities for public health protection, voluntary participation in registries and studies with privacy protection measures, and implementation through cooperative agreements. The program under paragraph (1) of the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act is carried out through a cooperative agreement with a medical institution or consortium located near the disaster area or areas where individuals worked or volunteered in response to the disaster. The program under the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act is carried out through a cooperative agreement with a medical institution or consortium near the disaster area. The individual involved in the program must have appropriate experience in environmental or occupational health, toxicology, safety, clinical protocols, health monitoring, epidemiological studies, mental health studies, and medical surveillance programs. The President shall involve interested and affected parties in establishing and maintaining a program under the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act, including representatives of government agencies, individuals who worked or volunteered in response to the disaster, local residents, businesses, schools, and health care providers. The President shall involve various parties in establishing and maintaining disaster relief programs, including government agencies, volunteers, residents, businesses, schools, and healthcare providers. Privacy regulations under the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act must be followed. Reports must be submitted to the Secretary of Homeland Security periodically. The President shall involve various parties in establishing and maintaining disaster relief programs, including government agencies, volunteers, residents, businesses, schools, and healthcare providers. Reports on programs and studies carried out under the program must be submitted to the Secretary of Homeland Security, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, the Secretary of Labor, the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, and appropriate committees of Congress. The National Academy of Sciences will report on health and environmental protection in the Hurricane Katrina and Rita disaster areas. The Secretary of Homeland Security, Health and Human Services, and EPA will contract the National Academy of Sciences to study disaster area health and environmental protection. The report will involve experts in various fields including environmental health, medicine, toxicology, and emergency planning. The report commissioned by the Secretary of Homeland Security, Health and Human Services, and EPA will provide advice and recommendations on emergency planning, public outreach, first responders, public health services, environmental justice, and health disparities. It will also include protocols for monitoring and responding to chemical releases in disasters. The report will provide guidance on monitoring and responding to chemical or substance releases in disaster areas to protect public health and safety, including sample collection, analysis methods, threshold levels, and response actions. The curr_chunk discusses procedures for providing monitoring results to government agencies, response personnel, and the public, as well as the responsibilities of agencies for sample collection, analysis, and response actions in the event of a disaster. It also addresses the capabilities of the Federal Government for environmental monitoring and response, including in the case of a terrorist attack. Authorization of Appropriations: Sums necessary for implementation authorized. SEC. 4. PREDISASTER HAZARD MITIGATION amended to change the date from December 31, 2008, to September 30, 2010. SEC. 5. Amends the Public Health Service Act to include community outreach and education programs to address health disparities.
